scenes.location: UPPER EAST SIDE NEW YORK CITY
characters: A BANK STACK OF U.S. CURRENCY
A HOTEL ROOM ACROSS THE HALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the pristine blocks of brownstones where even the garbage seems gift wrapped.  The VOICES continue over as we move in on a particular building where a DOORMAN is holding open the door for a dowager and her poodle. The voices continue:  "Hit me"... "Double down"... "Let i ride"... "Hit me"... "Anymore for the come out"... "Card"... In contrast to the outside of this sedate, quiet brownstone, we go inside to find...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... a miniature Las Vegas, complete with music, drinks, tuxedoed dealers and croupiers:  roulette, craps, Black Jack.  Wall to wall people.  The fact that casino gamblin happens to be illegal in New York doesn't stop these Connecticut slummers, hollow-cheek nightlifers, and junio wiseguys from having a good time.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE CARD TABLE
dialogues.text: NICK CONKLIN, holding a dollar cigar, is trying to pull a winning hand.  In his late thirties, Nick has the sort of quiet good looks that takes an extra glance to appreciate His Moe Ginsburg rent-a-tux is too tight, his ruffled shirt, out of date; Nick could care less. Two other players are still in the game.  One of them is lithe DEBUTANTE surrounded by an entourage of giggling friends and tuxedoed men.  The pot is huge. Nick flips two one hundred dollar chips onto the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, and one on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: House sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I'm out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusted, he throws down his cards. It's down to Nick and the debutante.  The cocky deb gives Nick a long look, confident she can win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her eyes still on Nick) I see the deuce, and one to chase them home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws her chips on the pot.  Nick hesitates, then decides to match it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing her hand) Ladies, aces wired.  Sorry sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick turns over his cards, Jacks and tens, not good enoug to win.  Elated, the deb gets up from the table and joins her giggling friends.  Nick walks over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice, Barbie. (pointing toward her boyfriend) Now, I'd take Ken over there and go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lady wants to play.  Someone should teach you to be a better loser, loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Ken --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is not Ken --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm offering you the benefit of my experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you have a lot of experience in places like this.  It was nice of them to relax the dress code for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That draws a laugh from her friends.  The entourage heads for the bar. CHARLIE SKLOARIS, twenty-three, steps in front of the debutante, blocking her path. She steps to the side.  Charlie steps with her.  Charlie' pushing it, he's always pushing it.  She's not amused. Finally, Charlie lets her pass.  He comes up to Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typical New York woman, big attitude, small apartment, no tits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only two things count to Charlie:  his job and his women, but not necessarily in that order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she got to you, pappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) You want a popsicle, go to Good Humor.  And don't call me 'pappy.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at the door) Still, you gotta wonder how she'd look in handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, wary, eyes this kid.  Charlie shrugs, spreads his arms defensively.  The SOUND of pounding on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: splinters.  The bouncer steps back as four helmeted emergency service officers -- the first members of the raiding party -- rush in. Pandemonium.  People rush for the exit -- any exit.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: Nick and Charlie hold up their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Alley oop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They down their drinks, then set them down. Charlie pulls out the Binaca, offering Nick a spritz, but Nick is already pulling out his POLICE BADGE and hanging it around his neck.  Charlie quickly follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: A HALF DOZEN COPS
dialogues.text: line the patrons up against the wall.  The Asst. D.A., PATTY ZACHARA, climbs onto the crap table.  A petite, nervous woman, Patty has dressed in a Channel suit for th occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settle down.  Hey, quiet... Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHUT THE HELL UP, GODDAMNIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That quiets them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Conklin.  Let's do this fast so I can go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zachara, annoyed, looks at Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softer) It's all yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads) Under section 216 of the New York State Penal code, I serve notice that this premise and it's occupants...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: catches the Debutante's eye across the room.  She smiles at him, he was right.  He shrugs, spreads his hands. That's life. A well groomed middle aged man, who we'll come to know as CAVELLO, suddenly bolts from the crowd lined up against the wall. Charlie spins around to stop him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa -- where do you think you're going, hotdog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavello butts him with his head, sending Charlie to the floor.  Then, crosses his arms in front of his face and plunges through the WINDOW. Nick, not missing a beat, gives a small sigh as he follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Fabulous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, short of breath, chases Cavello down the residentia street, past the dog-walkers, past the doormen, past the fur-coated women climbing out of taxies... Unfortunately, Cavello has a good half block on him. From nowhere, Charlie blasts past leaving Nick a half block behind, silently cursing his age.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE CORNER
dialogues.text: a limo jerks to a halt, and Cavello jumps in.  The limo streaks away.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: turns to see Nick, hands on knees, gasping for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in their street clothes, Charlie and Nick stand in front of the mirrors.  Charlie is working his brush and hair dryer as if his life depended on it.  Nick, in contrast, shoves his hair back with his fingers and glowers at himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the dryer) ... It's not like you were slow or anything... I think you did just fine.  I think you did great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick strides out the door.  Charlie hurries after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait up.  You know the guy who did the Weismuller through the window --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Cavello.  Ronnie Cavello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie trails Nick to his motorcycle:  a Harley hog complete with wide gleaming fenders and twin tanks.  The bike is held together with tape and baling wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick tries to kick-start this behemoth, but it's not easy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works for Frank Abolofia. Atlantic City.  Casinos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why dive through the glass for a nickel and dime bust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie puts his foot up on Nick's fender to tie his shoe Nick, spotting an ankle holster peeking from Charlie's sock, grabs Charlie's foot.  Charlie teeters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick pulls out a Beretta 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not regulation.  And the only way you're gonna stop anybody with it is to show it to him, and while he's laughing, you can shove it down his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Nick's bike) I'll get rid of it when you get rid of the egg-beater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Harley comes to life spitting a cloud of blue smoke. Nick puts on his paint-flecked helmet, slides down some ski goggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, let's go hunting.  Bag Cavello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick pops the bike into gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You still got shaving cream on your ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick rolls out and disappears in a haze of blue smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE FIND Nick, a lonely, solitary figure bobbing in and ou of the lights and shadows.  The SOUND of wind whips through his helmet; cold air stings his cheeks... The tai lights of Nick's bike disappear into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Civil service heaven.  Nick hits the cut switch and glide past the manicured lawns and well kept houses of this development.  A basketball net in every driveway, a Buick or Chrysler in every garage. One house sticks out.  The lawn is brown, paint is peelin off the garage door and newspapers are scattered on the driveway.  Nick glides once around the cul de sac looking at the house.  His house.  It's as inviting as an open grave.  He shoots away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hanger sized roadhouse, wall to wall red velvet. Nick's the sole figure at the counter, coffee and the Daily News in front of him.  A NURSE walks in and sits down a half dozen seats away.  Nick look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short shift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I came to save you.  If you're hopeless, I'll pull the plug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Connie are in bed.  They're both looking up at the ceiling.  They've just made love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting too cold even for me, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, how's the new partner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High spirits, desire, commitment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll take care of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a break, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you give me one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick kisses her.  The first suggestion of real affection. The SOUND of someone KNOCKING on the door.  Reluctantly, they stop.  Connie gets up and puts on her robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you expecting anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't expecting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She disappears down the hallway.  We HEAR the door open, then telling someone to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (poking her head in the room) Imagine a small, greasy Boy Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, wearing only his pants, is doing a slow burn. Charlie is holding his hands up defensively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I found the goombah... Cavello. He's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I should tear your head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, I knew you were going to say that.  I absolutely anticipated that, Nick.  But I said to myself, Charlie, Charlie, we can move up on this, so go find Nicklaus... He'll be pissed for a moment, but then it'll dawn on him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Hey, I got a better chance of being hit by a bus then moving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks away momentarily, letting it slide.  He knows he's on sensitive ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Look... they told me at the Greek's you were here.  I'm sorry, I never imagined...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (buddy buddy) I like her.  She's nice. (lowering his voice) For her age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom door opens.  Connie enters, dumps Nick's clothes on the couch, tosses his gun on top of the pile. Without a word, she goes back inside and slams the door behind her. Nick, pissed, slowly turns to face Charlie.  Charlie shrugs.  Nick's got nothing better to do than go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lime House is a little piece of Italy in the heart of Chinatown, and tonight, it's packed.  Any selection on th jukebox that isn't Frank Sinatra is Jerry Vale.  Behind the bar are two fat BROTHERS.  One pours drinks, the othe dishes out Scungilli.  It's three a.m.  It's always three a.m. at the Lime House.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BACK TABLE
dialogues.text: Our man CAVELLO is unloading steaming Scungilli onto an already heaping plate in front of an imperious looking JAPANESE MAN.  The Japanese Man, in his mid-fifties, wear a gray suit, and not a strand of his jet black hair is ou of place. A Japanese TRANSLATOR, doing his best to translate Cavello's heavily accented English, sits between them.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: Charlie is looking straight ahead, afraid Cavello might peg him.  Nick is at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eating Scungilli, just like the last time you asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think the Jap is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Cavello's buying a Subaru. How would I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you for being sore. It'll pass when we bag him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, trying to relax, gestures toward his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatdaya think?  'Bostonians'. Eighty-five bucks. (lowering his voice) Girls go for shoes.  Second place they look. (off Nick's reaction) Hey, I read it in a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick's attention is drawn to a trio walking in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dead serious) Charlie, don't do anything.  Promise me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT THEY SEE:  TWO BODYGUARDS are making a quick sweep o the bar.  FRANK ABOLOFIA, s stocky man with silver grey hair, sweeps in behind them.  Abolofia has mitts like a meat packer and a fifty dollar manicure.  A heavyweight Mafioso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Abolofia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wolf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abolofia walks to Cavello's table.  All rise and shake hands.  The two hitters take seats at the bar.  The two brothers scramble to serve their distinguished guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Some party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should do something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, take your gum, stick it under your ass and keep it warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick turns away, resumes his drink. NICK'S POV IN THE MIRROR BEHIND THE BAR:  two new Japanes men step in the door.  Early twenties, spiky hair, dark Versace suits.

dialogues.speaker: NUMBER ONE
dialogues.text: wears tortoise shell shades.  He coolly checks out the room then nods to --

dialogues.speaker: NUMBER TWO
dialogues.text: who pulls a Spas 12, automatic shotgun from under his coat, and spits out three rounds.  A window shatters. Everyone hits the floor.

dialogues.speaker: NUMBER ONE
dialogues.text: slowly walks toward Cavello's table.

dialogues.speaker: NUMBER TWO
dialogues.text: covers the floor.  Abolofia's bodyguards show their empty hands.

dialogues.speaker: NICK AND CHARLIE
dialogues.text: on the floor.  They don't have the artillery for this guy either.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Our Japanese businessman knows these people.  He eyes the contemptuously. Abolofia has put enough people in this situation to be philosophical about it.  He stops chewing.  A tiny hand motion to his bodyguards is enough to stop any precipitous action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Japanese) Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Japanese businessman looking straight ahead.  A long, silent pause... Then, still not facing him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Japanese) Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number One slips his fingers beneath his shades, massagin his eyes.  IN A FLASH, he pulls a shuto from under his coat.  The 18 inch blade gleams like a neon tube. He presses the tip of the blade against the businessman's throat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: his hand close around the grip of the Beretta.  He unsnap the ankle holster.  The SNAP can be heard across the room Nick's hand closes around Charlie's and squeezes till the knuckles turn white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saving your life.

dialogues.speaker: NUMBER TWO
dialogues.text: levels the scattergun at Nick and Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: calmly holds the blade at the man's throat as he reaches into the man's jacket and removes a small, rectangular, plastic-wrapped parcel. He feels its weight, then flips it to NUMBER TWO. Abolofia, realizing that whatever is going on doesn't affect him or his, resumes eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people are wild... Wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUMBER ONE backs the blade off.  The man raises his napki to the small wound.  A droplet of blood has stained his shirt collar.  NUMBER ONE turns around as if to leave. What happens next could be a whim, an after thought. Number One spins around and THRUSTS the blade deep into the man's chest.  He withdraws it with a half twist, and in the same motion fatally slashes the translator's throa before the old man's body hits the floor. Blood pours from the businessman's mouth onto his Scungilli, spreading across the white cloth and onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CAVELLO
dialogues.text: reaches for a gun under his coat.  But NUMBER TWO pumps two rounds into his face.  At this range, there's not muc left. The killers slowly back out the door, covering the room with the scattergun.  The minute the door shuts, Nick leaps up, pulling his shield and revolver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Police officers.  Everybody stay put. (to Charlie) Get back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abolofia's eyebrows rise at this development. Nick bolts out the door leaving Charlie in charge.  He's never been in charge before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously showing shield) Police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Lincoln tears around the corner to pick the killers up. Nick flies out the Lime House door and hits the ground. Number Two pumps out shells as fast as he can squeeze the trigger.  He's wild.  The front windows of the Lime House shatter. The LIMO DRIVER jerks to a halt.  Number Two tosses the package to him. Nick empties his revolver.  Number Two goes down. The driver floors the accelerator, leaving Number One to take off on foot.  Nick follows, reloading as he runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's frozen on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call 911.  Tell them an officer needs assistance.  Say ten thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing from the owner who looks at Abolofia.  Charlie grabs the owner by his collar and shoves him toward the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it, you dumb bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Charlie feels something wet at his feet.  He looks down to see that he's standing in a pool of blood from the massacre.  So much for his new shoes. He wheels around, then quickly backs out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted.  The wail of police sirens in the distance. Charlie has his gun out.  He's drenched in sweat.  Where is his partner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK...!  Shit... SHIT!!

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER STREET
dialogues.text: Nick, gun drawn, slowly rounds the corner to the alley: it's the ad hoc drugstore for the night.  Drugs going up and down in pails, two dozen junkies buying, shooting, slumped on the ground.  Everyone scatters -- the one's that can.

dialogues.speaker: AN ABANDONED PAIL
dialogues.text: swings slowly back and forth from three stories up.  Nick cautiously moves down the alley, holding the gun in both hands.  A Junkie steps out of a doorway, Nick swings his gun and nearly blows him away.

dialogues.speaker: NUMBER ONE
dialogues.text: We see his eyes first as he steps out of the darkness at the back of the alley.  From now on we'll call him KOBO. His sunglasses are on his forehead; his hands dropped casually at his side.  A very cool character. Kobo slowly raises his hand, and making a gun with his finger, slowly points and "shoots" at Nick... He lowers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the ground, man.  NOW!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kobo cups his hands around his ear.  He doesn't understan English.  Nick, keeping his gun fixed, comes up to him an kicks out his legs. Kobo falls flat on his chest. Nick pulls out his cuffs.  But Kobo lunges for Nick's ankle and yanks it toward him.  Nick stumbles backward; Kobo's on his feet.  Before Nick can stand, Kobo lands a brutal kick to the side of Nick's head. Nick gets up, barrels into him.  Kobo knees Nick in the solar plexus, then lands two more well placed kicks in Nick's back.  It's not that Nick's a bad fighter, it's that this kid is so damn fast. Nick slowly gets to his feet.  KOBO lands two more brutal shots to the side of Nick's head.  He's a bloody mess.

dialogues.speaker: TWO POLICE CARS
dialogues.text: stop at the end of the alley.  FOUR OFFICERS climb out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: joins the cops as they run down the alley to find Nick getting pummeled. Charlie shoots at Kobo.  Misses.  Kobo turns to see the five cops, guns drawn. Nick, on one knee, spits out blood and a few teeth. Kobo calmly slips the shuto out of his coat pocket and drops it next to Nick.  The blade gleams in the light. That was next.  Nick got lucky. Kobo towers imperiously above Nick.  Their eyes lock.  We hold then...

dialogues.speaker: NICK'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: There isn't a stick of furniture, but that's not the half of it.  In the middle of the room is a motorcycle on a centerstand.  A drop cloth is spread around it, tools neatly aligned.  It's a Harley -- but this one is in perfect condition. A phone RINGS insistently from off screen, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... sure, sure I'll be down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick walks in, naked.  Every muscle aches.  One side of his face is completely swollen.  He has a band-aid over his right eye; some blood caked on his earlobe.  He stops to twist a spark plug in with a ratchet, but it snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPT. OLIVER, early forties, walks between Charlie and Nick as they head toward the Medical Examiner's room. Oliver doesn't face Nick as he speaks; no love lost between these two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How big a package we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up his hands) This by this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in that company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man was a Japanese paper manufacturer.  Hotel room and rental car were full of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Art and stationary paper.  Cavello had five hundred thousand in his attache case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick rubs the back of his neck in obvious pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One guy do all the damage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you knew your way around dark alleys, detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver goes through the swinging doors into the Examiner' room.  Charlie shoots Nick a look.  Nick let's it slide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TECHIE is showing the night's harvest to Charlie, Nick and Oliver.  They're standing over the body of the middle aged Japanese man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The old man's suit was Japanese. The hitter's was Saville row.  No I.D.  We're doing a peel now.

dialogues.speaker: AT ANOTHER TABLE
dialogues.text: Another techie is carefully removing the skin from Number Two's fingertips. Charlie shuts his eyes and turns away, trying not to thro up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something you got to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whips back the sheet, the body is nude.  A towel cover the genitals.  Except for the feet, hands, neck, and face the body is covered with elaborate tattoos:  flowers and blood, dragons and snakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with this picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) I got a tattoo.  Birdie on the ball. We all got them when we finished basic at Camp Lejune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you guys were trained observers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up surprised.  The techie picks up a hand.  The third and forth fingers have been neatly amputated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight fingers. (ironically) Hey, it was a trick question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABOLOFIA is seated in chair next to his LAWYER.  Nick, Oliver, and a third detective are grilling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was with a friend, sure.  I shake hands with the guy and a minute later he's bleeding all over my socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will that do officers?  My client has had a terrible shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's not used to seeing other people do the killing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't tolerate harassment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the package?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know nothing about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  Abolofia looks at Nick, then at Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to believe a trained police officer could let this kind of thing happen right in front of his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did make a mistake.  I let the wrong guy get hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abolofia doesn't blink an eye, goes for the jugular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheer up, Nick.  I'm sure it's easier to pick a dead man's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick springs from his feet.  Oliver grabs Nick before he can get close to Abolofia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, we're through!

dialogues.speaker: KOBO
dialogues.text: the Japanese killer who smashed in Nick's face last night He's sitting in an interrogation room an hour later with DETECTIVE and a JAPANESE TRANSLATOR.  He won't talk.

dialogues.speaker: OBSERVATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Nick and Oliver watching through the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't speak a word of English. And he won't speak Japanese either. No papers.  The Japanese embassy is very interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's wanted in Japan.  They want him first.  Then we can have him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver nods.  That's the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: ON KOBO
dialogues.text: he turns and looks at Nick.  He can't possibly see him through the one way glass but he knows Nick's there.

dialogues.speaker: ON NICK
dialogues.text: looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: ON KOBO
dialogues.text: making a cutting mark across his forehead, right where Nick's bandage is.  It's uncanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick is sitting in front of Oliver's desk.  The sunlight makes him wince; wincing makes his face hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Japanese embassy talks to state department.  State talks to police plaza.  They to me and me to you. Shit rolls down hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver drops a file folder on the desk.  Nick opens it: petty cash, vouchers and plane tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Charlie are taking the Jap home, tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...?  What if I say no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check your gun before you leave. They're not allowed in Japan.  It's a nice, safe country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said send a detective if I could spare one. (then) I can always spare you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick bridles at the insult.  Oliver's had a hard-on for Nick for years, and Nick's tired of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) You got something to say to me, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver doesn't want to get into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Have a wonderful flight.

dialogues.speaker: THE ORANGE SUN
dialogues.text: on the tail of a Japan Airlines 747.  A driving rain storm.  The plane taxies down the runway and disappears into the black rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kobo, handcuffed and shackled, is in the center seat. Nick and Charlie sit on either side.  Charlie is holding "Bachelors Japan" in one hand.  Nick's in a sour mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Nick, you're the one that's always saying you never go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking the Poconos, Charlie. Maybe Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you missing?  Riding your motorcycle to the nurse's house. That shit is sadder than Ethiopia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats forty hours on a plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say we got to turn around and come right back.  That's what they say.  I got a plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last thing Nick wants to hear -- too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call, right?  I say I got the dreaded thirty six-hour Asian shits from some raw clam and we stretch it into three days.  You and I become a driving force on the local Geisha scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Hey, come on, big guy like you, cop from New York.  You're gonna be the biggest thing to hit town since Godzilla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick can't help but smile at this kid.  Charlie looks dow at the guide book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says here, it's very impolite to touch someone while you're talking to them... (nudges Kobo) Guess that means you can't talk and screw at the same time, huh, hotdog? What's the matter, no -- speaky-the- language?  Understand this:  You will never ever fuck with my partner again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing from Kobo who is looking straight ahead.  He doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut-up, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then Charlie reads a Japanese phrase from the book.  A slight facial response from Kobo.  Charlie tries it again.  This time Kobo laughs openly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the subway station, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kobo keeps laughing; it's obviously not what Charlie said

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a new book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabin is now darkened.  Kobo and Nick are asleep.  No Charlie, he's still at his book, and listening to U2 on his Walkman.  Nick rolls over and opens his eyes to see Charlie watching him.  He shuts them hoping to avoid talk Too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick... You up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie removes his headphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, have I been a good partner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number five with a bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want you to know... I mean anybody who says you ever took has got to deal with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to sleep, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't take, did you...?  You hear things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I worked the three nine in Queens, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) I didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lieutenant was on the pad along with the rest of the squad.  I was new, didn't know shit.  When the feathers flew, I got called in front of the special prosecutor.  It's on the top of my personnel file.  They think I'm dirty or I cut a deal. Doesn't leave you with a lot of friends either way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might as well have done something. I've been paying for it every goddamn day since I got transferred...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD on Nick then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Charlie, with Kobo between them, are a strange sight in a sea of Japanese faces.  Kobo's hands are cuffe behind his back.  Nick also has Kobo cuffed to his wrist. The cops are rumpled, exhausted, showing two days of stubble.  Kobo looks sharp and wide awake. A pair of attractive teenage girls walks past them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa.  Nick, we're in paradise.

dialogues.speaker: A PAIR
dialogues.text: of white gloved hands belonging to a Tokyo police officer holds up a small, hand letter sign that says: CONKLIN/SKLOARIS.  The man holding the sign is NAGASHIMA. Two other police officers in spotless tan uniforms stand at his side. Nick, holding Kobo by his arm, steps up to the police and show his I.D.  Nagashima bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officers Conklin and -- and... (he can't say Charlie's name) ... gentlemen, welcome.  I am assistant inspector Nagashima.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They show their I.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to take this crap off our hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) Crap...?  Oh, the prisoner.  Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He barks some orders to the officers who immediately take Kobo by the arms and put cuffs on him.  Nick unfastens his cuff when they're through. In contrast to Nagashima's gentility, the cops are rough with the prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extends his hand) Charlie.  Kon-ich-iwa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nagashima shakes his hand.  Bows.  Charlie bows back. Nick wouldn't bow if his life depended on it.  Nagashima hands Nick an official looking document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you will please give this to the customs inspector he will expidate -- expedite you.  We have a car and a driver outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bows) Arigato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick grabs Charlie by the arm and starts for the customs line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Givin' you a book is like givin' a baby a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, when in Rome --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Rome, I'll bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK and CHARLIE make their way through the crowd toward the head of a long line.  They dump their bags on the counter.  The INSPECTOR, furious that they have taken cut in line, barks at them in Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector Nagashima told me to give you this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the Inspector the official looking document.  Th Inspector scans the paper.  Hands it back to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (broken English) You must get in line behind the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're cops.  Pol-ice-men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector signals a nearby POLICEMAN.  The Inspector says something in Japanese.  Hands the policeman the document.  The policeman shakes his head, amused, points to the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellas, get serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From off screen someone CALLS OUT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Charlie turn to see KOBO, their prisoner, standing on the other side of the thick plastic divider. The handcuffs are off.  The three alleged 'policemen' are heading out the door behind him.  It was a set-up:  Nick and Charlie have been had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perfect English) Thanks for the ride, detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slowly backs away from the glass as if he had all the time in the world, finally disappearing in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: NICK AND CHARLIE
dialogues.text: trying to shove past the customs inspectors who are wrestling them aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops!  He's our prisoner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two more policemen arrive.  Nick and Charlie are thrown u against the wall.  Out come the cuffs.  SNAP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?  We're the good guys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty identical desks.  Fifty identical phones.  Fifty identically dressed men in white shirts and ties working under the fluorescent lights of this large open room. We GLIDE PAST the rows of desk to find INSPECTOR OHASHI, mid forties, sitting behind a perfectly arranged desk. Ohashi prides himself on order. Nick and Charlie are standing in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me something like an Identi-Kit and I'll give you a description.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohashi remains poker faced.  He continues to arrange papers and apply his hanko (personal seal) to the bottom of a stack of official papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be some witnesses from the airport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still nothing from the good inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, tea time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still nothing from Ohashi.  Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet rage) You lost a man we wanted for some time.  It was very incompetent on your part, officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incompetent is letting people waltz through a secure area wearing your uniforms, carrying official documents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohashi bows slightly, we're not sure why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not allowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're police officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're foreigners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work with me.  I want your best detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.  Ohashi returns to his papers.  Nick can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, inspector, I don't intend to take the rap for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Do you know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohashi holds up the document that was handed to Nick at the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a laundry list.  Go home, detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick studies him for a beat, then turns away.  To Charlie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, we can't just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said let's go, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly they head towards the door, passing long rows of bureaucrats, telephones ringing off the hook.  Nick stops at the door, spots a fuse box nearby.  He glances back to make sure no one is looking. Nick pulls out his handcuffs.  Charlie can't figure out what the hell he's doing.  Nick attaches one cuff to the main lever then yanks it down. The lights go out.  The fan's stop; so do the typewriters so does the air conditioning.  Dead silence. Nick attaches the other cuff to a pipe, snaps it shut. Now it's impossible to left the main lever. From the far end of the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick drops the key down the water fountain drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your best detective, Ohashi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Charlie cross the street.  Charlie's trying to read the name from the piece of paper Ohashi has given them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Detective Ich-iro Matsu-moto. Hey, we're getting Mr. Moto on our side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's grab some food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First decent idea you've had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie pulls out his 'Footloose in Tokyo" book, flips through the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Food... Food, here we go.  Tokyo offers a wide variety of food.  It's best to sample the local specialties, including sashaimi, soba, and world renown Kobe beef...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick goes into a restaurant.  Charlie drops the book, disgusted with Nick's choice.  Charlie reluctantly follow him in.  REVEAL it's a Shakey's Pizza restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rows of post-modern buildings of odd shaped windows and brightly painted concrete walls.  Nick and Charlie are searching for the Japanese cop's building.  They can't speak the language; they can't read the signs; and half the buildings don't have numbers.  It's a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This should be it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that in the last two places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie holds out the paper to a passing man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kore?  Doku?  Kore doku?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man gestures toward the building Charlie was pointing to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you were right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie grins, satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are knocking on a door.  Nick turns the handle. It's unlocked.

dialogues.speaker: THE APARTMENT
dialogues.text: A four tatami room.  An unholy mess:  Food packages, beer bottles, stacks of papers and file folders.  Framed pictures of long dead relatives hang on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This the right place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN now appears at the door.  Middle aged, wizened face, in a full traditional Kimono.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Konichiwa.  Ichiro Matsumoto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman babbles bird-like in rapid Japanese.  She bows. They're in the right place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jammed streets are barely wide enough to get a motorcycle down.  It's a bad neighborhood, one of the poorest in Tokyo. We spot the small kimono clad WOMAN, clip-clopping on wooden geta, leading Nick and Charlie through this labyrinth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) Getting very weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd feel better if we had some heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should bail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing they've stopped, the woman gestures for them to hurry up, then disappears around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the maze of streets) Think we could find our way back?

dialogues.speaker: A GARISH PINK SIGN
dialogues.text: A poor man's idea of a bar.  The woman points inside, chirps away in Japanese, bows, then hurries off leaving Nick and Charlie on their own.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE PINK SARON
dialogues.text: Nick and Charlie disappear into darkness as the woven flaps shut behind them.  A vintage wurlitzer juke box glows across the room.  An Enka plays.  (Haunting Japanes blues.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big shots from New York.  I like your style!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ICHIRO MATSUMOTO steps into a pool of light just inches from them.  He is a short overweight man looking every minute of his fifty-five years.  His white short sleeve shirt is too tight; his narrow tie spotted in the middle; his collar soaked in sweat.  He's not drunk yet, but he's been at it a while.  Call him Ich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bowing) Detective Ichiro Matsumoto.  I'm the man you're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Ohashi's best man?  Well, at least he speaks English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man you are looking for, Kobo, was a member of the Samaguchi-gummi. A Yakuza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich nods, offers them what's left of his Sapphoro beer. They shake their heads.  Ich finishes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do we start looking for this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would you look for the mafia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back room at Lombardi's after the Columbus Day Parade.  Under the bed.  In the mayor's office. Everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich heads for the door without saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where're you going, Ichiro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops, faces them) The mayor's office, under the bed, the back room at Lombardi's. (tucking in his shirt tail) And call me Ich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine an ultra modern indoor shopping mall, except ther aren't any stores.  The only product sold here is pleasure:  Bars, hostess clubs, Turkish baths.  A post- modern red light district with music piped in and automated doormen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hip, younger Japanese are wedged together at the long chrome bar.  The GUYS sport leather jackets and Raybans. The GIRLS are decked out in fifties American party dresse and short cropped hair.  Jerry Lee Lewis wails in the background. Nick, Ich and Charlie are at one end of the long bar.  Ic is drinking them both under the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) "Goodness, gracious, great balls of fire." (raising glass for toast) To the killer.  Jerry Lee Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Jerry Lee Lewis, Elvis, Dinky Doo And The Don't's.  Let's book, Charlie.  If he starts on Motown, we'll be here all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is the place for the young Yakuza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you said in the last three piss pots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich sets down his drink, pours more sake for Nick and Charlie then for himself.  He's having a great time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you people.  The music, the clothes, the movies... Japanese respect only what is Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick glances at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's incredible.  Hit him or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he'd feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to slur his words) Americans change everything.  When I was young the city was wood and paper... I was ten when the bombers came.  I lived underground for three days.  When I came up, the city was gone... A ball of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick gets to his feet.  Ich grabs him by the arm, stoppin him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It began to rain, Nick.  You know what color the rain was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich doesn't give him a chance to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black... It was black from the ash. Very impressive.  You Americans, you could make black rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich polishes off his drink.  An awkward silence.  Charlie wanting to lighten the mood --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning close) Say Ich, between friends, where can I grab some squish around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick sighs, digs in his pocket for some yen for the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pussy, ass, soft personnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich looks up to see a picturesque, blood-haired American WOMEN in a tight silk blouse and skirt.  She works here and has obviously heard Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Joyce... (in Japanese) How are you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Japanese) Hello, Ich.  Johnny Walker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich nods.  Joyce's Japanese is impeccable.  She's a part- time bartender, translator, model.  One of Japan's wester wanderers.  She's sliding past thirty, but only her weary eyes give it away.  She is about to pour Ich another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give him any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets as much as he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie extends his hand to Joyce.  She ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello hello, Charlie Skloaris.  New York City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She refills Ich's glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My partner and I are cops. (lowering his voice) We're on a very big assignment here. (nothing from Joyce) When do you get off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right when you're being tucked into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be nicer to my American friends, Joyce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wouldn't appreciate it, Ich. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says something in Japanese to Ich as she eyes the cops.  Then, she walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce can be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightening) What'd she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile) That I should let you pay for the drinks. (raising his glass) Kampai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Nick are trying to help a besotted Ich find a taxi, but no one will take him.  Ich is shouting half English, half Japanese phrases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We got to keep looking.  Track him down!  Great balls of fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated, to a cabbie) What's the problem here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabbie ignores them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't speak the language.  I'll drop him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to see Joyce standing behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Joyce...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest is slurred Japanese.  Joyce speaks to a cabbie i Japanese.  The rear door swings open.  She helps Ich in. Joyce climbs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out the window) See you tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls away.  Nick and Charlie watch it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An early morning wind jostles the red paper lantern and plucks at the tails of dragon-like banners hanging outsid the shops.  Nick and Charlie are walking down this narrow sidestreet on the way back to their hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He's a sorry old guy, but I like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He couldn't find his ass with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brand new Kawasaki 1000 motorcycle with windshield and full farings gleams under a street light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's the kind of motorcycle I want to see you on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Sure, a rice burning crotch rocket...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, how we gonna bag this guy without any help?  Maybe I should work on that girl Joyce, she speaks the language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick glances over at his partner, smiles.  But before he can respond -- The DULL ROAR of a half dozen motorcycles in the distance breaks the pre-dawn stillness.

dialogues.speaker: TWENTY BOSOZOKU, (BIKERS)
dialogues.text: on their multi-cylinder high tech street bombers, creep around the corner and slowly ride toward Nick and Charlie We get a better look at them:  turbo punk Elvis-samurai hybrids -- some wearing a slipper under their headbands, courtesy of their girlfriends; some in leopard skin pants And tattoos... They head straight for Nick and Charlie, then, at the las moment, split and float away IN SLOW MOTION, as if the cops didn't exist. Suddenly, the street is empty again.  Silent except for the SOUND of the wind beating against paper lanterns, rustling the wind chimes... Hold on Nick and Charlie standing in the middle of the street, realizing just how far away from home they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rocket shaped building:  a mixture of Dutch Gable and Japanese Minka roof.  The mid-day sun beats down on a particular room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Charlie are sacked out.  They never bothered to pull the curtains.  THE SOUND OF KNOCKING at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give us a break...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Ichiro.  Ich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave the rice cake outside and go home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Ich persists.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOOR
dialogues.text: As Nick opens up.  Ich bows.  He's now clean shaven and has put on a clean shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's been a murder.  Yakuza.  You should come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murder scene.  NO SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: A BODY FROM THE WAIST DOWN in the claws of six foot working robotic.  The tattooed covered legs swing back an forth like a pendulum. THE TORSO is wedged in between two enormous printing rollers. THE HEAD is resting in the middle of a conveyer belt. It's been drenched in black printer's ink which has begun to congeal. WE SLOWLY TRACK PAST Ich, Charlie, and Nick, watching. Charlie has the dry heaves. REAL SOUND as we reveal the full crime scene.  Instead of the usual cigar smoke, camera flashes and radio chatter, there is order and quiet.  A slow underwater dance.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR OHASHI
dialogues.text: quietly gives an order.  Someone turns off the robotic. The severed legs stop swinging. Nick, Charlie and Ich walk over to Ohashi.  Ich bows deeply.  Ohashi doesn't acknowledge any of them, talks to a man holding a tape measurer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you fill me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask your chief detective?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich looks down at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I want you to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young are eating the old, something that usually doesn't happen here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we skip the poetry, inspector?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohashi pauses.  Ich looks at Nick as if to warn him he can't speak to Ohashi that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a war, detective, between two rival groups.  The man who escaped, Kobo, leads the younger group.  They did this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kobo's a wild boy.  He was a lieutenant in the Sammaguchi-gummi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Japanese) Excellent, Officer Matsumoto.  How is your investigation going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Japanese) Well, sir.  Thank you for giving me the opportunity to work with these distinguished gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows.  It's pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for clues in the bottom of a sake bottle, Matsumoto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an officer of great distinction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another sarcastic dig.  Ich stoically stands and takes it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ich has been helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him, to Nick) Have you changed your mind and decided to go home, detective?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until one of us bags Kobo. (looking at the corpse) And it doesn't look like you're doing so hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohashi coolly flicks the ashes of his cigarette and we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich, Nick, and Charlie are threading their way through th crowd toward the subway entrance. TWO BIKERS, their hair slicked back, watch the trio from the top of two different subway entrances. As soon as Ich, Nick and Charlie go down the steps, they climb off their bikes and follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, Ich and Charlie are riding the people mover that stretches the length of this endless tunnel.  They're sandwiched between the legions of SALARYMEN (white collar workers) who all wear identical blue suits and white shirts. Nick looks over at Ich, who is still suffering in silence from the recent humiliation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Inspector, you take shit once, you take shit forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I don't deserve Ohashi's respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich looks away, obviously uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cool, Ich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?  You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does Ichiro mean, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) What does Charlie mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie slaps Ich on the back. NICK smiles at Charlie's remark.  He can't help but like this wide-eyed goofy kid. Something makes Nick's smile fade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KOBO, their escaped prisoner, hurrying in the opposite direction.  His Kamali suit looks like it just came from the cleaners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie spots him.  In a flash, the two men jump the railing and charge after him, leaving Ich in their wake. Ich can't possibly make it over the side.  He furiously shoves his way through the Salarymen, trying to get to th end of the walkway.

dialogues.speaker: CHASE SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: -- Nick barreling through the mass of faceless Salarymen. -- Kobo, hurrying ahead, occasionally glancing back. -- Charlie catching up to Nick.  They've lost him.  They spin around.  A half dozen tunnels spin out in all directions. -- Nick and Charlie spotting Kobo.  He's waiting for them near the turnstile. Nick suddenly realizes it's a set-up.  Before he can say anything, Charlie sprints ahead, recklessly shoving people out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him) It's a set-up...!  Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie hasn't heard him.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TURNSTILE
dialogues.text: Kobo hands a ticket to the turnstile guard and disappears onto the platform.  Charlie doesn't have a ticket.  The guard points to the automatic ticket machine.  Screw it. Charlie leaps over the turnstile. The GUARD blows his shrill whistle to signal the subway police.

dialogues.speaker: THE PLATFORM
dialogues.text: Charlie pushes through the crowd -- a wall of blank faces Kobo is gone.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: shoving through the crowd.  He spots Charlie.  Shouts at him to wait.  Charlie can't hear his partner.

dialogues.speaker: THE SUBWAY
dialogues.text: pulls in.  An immaculately uniformed CONDUCTOR blows his whistle and waves his white-gloved hands to keep the crow back. A LEATHER JACKETED BOY shoves Charlie from behind; he stumbles forward toward the track.  Someone catches him a the last moment.  Charlie turns around to see it's Kobo. Kobo smiles, it's all a big joke. What follows happens in a flash:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick is close enough to see, too far to do anything.  He' blocked by TWO MORE LEATHER BOYS.  He tries to shove past but they grab him.

dialogues.speaker: KOBO
dialogues.text: holding Charlie by his coat lapels.  An express train tears into the station.  Kobo casually glances at

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: trying to struggle free.

dialogues.speaker: KOBO
dialogues.text: his eyes still on Nick, drops Charlie in front of the speeding express as if he were a sack of laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman SCREAMS. The train barrels through the station. Kobo starts toward Nick.  He's next. A pair of SUBWAY POLICEMEN burst through the crowd searching for Charlie because he vaulted the turnstile.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: manages to break free of the leatherboys holding him. They flee into the crowd as the police close in.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE PLATFORM
dialogues.text: slips into the wave of commuters being shoved into a train by white-gloved MEN.  It's their job to shove commuters into the already packed cars. Nick goes for Kobo, but the crowd closes in front of him. He can't get through.

dialogues.speaker: THE SUBWAY DOORS
dialogues.text: slam shut.  The train pulls out leaving Nick standing on the empty platform.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAST CAR
dialogues.text: streaks past him.  Kobo stands in the rear window, gettin smaller and smaller until the train disappears down the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich, out of breath, is standing on the platform.  Nick looks at him with disgust -- where the hell was he. STAY on Nick, his head bowed, being surrounded by the sea of blue-suited commuters.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: NICK'S FACE against a white wall.  That's all we see. Ohashi's voice OFF SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You ignored me.  I don't care about what you want.  Get on a plane, detective Conklin.  Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR a door open and SLAM shut off screen.  Hold on Nick, frozen in place, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, the fifty desks, fifty faceless men working. Typewriters CLACKING, phones RINGING.  We MOVE down the rows to find Nick sitting behind one of the desks.  He's on the phone to New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was my partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're blaming it on you.  Christ, Conklin, you didn't even tell me you lost the prisoner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I planned on catching him, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?  You don't know the place.  You don't know the language.  Get on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He killed a police officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your plane's at nine a.m.  Be on it. That's orders.  Period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver hangs up.  A moment of long distance hum cross talk.  Nick doesn't move.  Pull back through the rows of cops busily working... SOUND FADES. Charlie Parker's alto sax FADE UP as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC continues.  The sax screams as the melody is abandoned. Nick is drunk.  Roaring angry drunk.  He doesn't know where he is.  He doesn't care.  He plows down the street, occasionally grabbing a passerby, then letting them go. Nick begins to laugh.  A couple is staring at him, Nick yells at them, but we DON'T HEAR HIM.  He stumbles on... drop back to find.

dialogues.speaker: ICH
dialogues.text: following in his wake.  He bows and apologizes to the offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick is thrown onto the street.  He tries to reenter and is thrown out again.  We spot JOYCE inside watching; she turns back to her customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick is hassling a news vendor who pointedly ignores him and continues selling his papers.  Ich appears and apologizes to the news vendor. EXT.  STREET - TWO A.M. Nick's sitting on the curb, his head in his hands.  Peopl step around him. Across the street, out of Nick's sight, Ich is watching his partner, feeling every barb of Nick's shame. Charlie Parker continues over the slow...

dialogues.speaker: NICK --
dialogues.text: asleep, the futon tangled around him.  He opens his eyes. A woman is making tea in the kitchenette.  This is the kimonoed woman who led Nick and Charlie to Ich the other night. A RADIO is on softly in the background.  The Charlie Parker tune we've been listening to over the previous cut ends, and the announcer comes on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That was the Bird, from the Blue Note years.  1230 hours and 72 degrees in central Osaka.  This is specialist Doug Dale, Tapestries in Jazz, on the Far East Network, armed forces radio...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick slowly sits up to see

dialogues.speaker: ICH
dialogues.text: seated at a low table looking at him from across the room Nick spots his clothes and luggage stacked in the corner. Nick now realizes he's in Ich's apartment.  It's spotless Everything is now in its proper place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They made you leave your hotel... (looks away) ... you caused a disturbance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick's eyes fall on Charlie's things:  his sports clothes his tour book, his shoes which Ich has stacked on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may be too soon to talk about it. When someone we care for dies we... (beat) ... keep something of their's.  A tie, a pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why weren't you at the platform?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't keep up.  My shame is complete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick slowly shuts his eyes, his head pounding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighborhood bathhouse.  Thick with steam and neighborhood kids. Nick walks toward the huge pool of water.  Ich is beside him.  Nick's about to climb in when Ich stops him, hands him a pail and a washcloth and points to the faucets alon the wall where a dozen men squat on small stools as they wash themselves.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: as he pours a pail of water over his head, it runs down his face in slow motion.

dialogues.speaker: THE POOL
dialogues.text: Nick soaking, on one side.  Ich is soaking nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get him for you, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick looks at this thick bellied, alcoholic cop.  Not a very reassuring thought. TWO MEN carrying plastic pails cross in front of the tub. Young, muscular Yakuza, their bodies covered with exquisite tattoos.  They stare openly at Nick.  One makes a joke.  Both laugh obscenely as they slip into the hot tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yakuza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich nods.  Nick eyes them for a long beat, then climbs ou of the tub.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nick tossing two bags into a taxi in front of Ich's apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: ICH
dialogues.text: Ich watching Nick through the window from inside his apartment.  He glances back and sees Charlie's "Members Only" coat hanging on a hook. When he turns back, Nick's taxi has disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brightest object in the frame is a yellow forklift carrying a jostling aluminum coffin toward the open belly of the cargo plane.  Nick watches it from the edge of the tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT CHECK IN GATE
dialogues.text: Nick hands the clerk his ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aisle or window?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick spots a folded newspaper someone has left on the counter.  He can't read it, of course, but there's a picture of the subway platform where Charlie was killed, swarming with police.  Nick continues to stare at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aisle or window, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up) I want to cash it in.  Yen.

dialogues.speaker: ICH'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Nick steps in, drops the two suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ichiro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman steps out of the kitchen, babbles something in Japanese.  Nick doesn't have a clue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a handful of patrons.  Joyce is straightening bottle behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's tricks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up, surprised to see Nick standing in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich said you left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a change in plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick's surprised at how fast she heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead gaiijin's are big news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaiijin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outside person.  A foreigner.  A barbarian.  You, me. (beat) More you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could use some help.  Show me around.  I'll pay you for your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give tours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can count on the truth from people who don't like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a helluva way of asking for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a helluva way of answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you need Ich.  I've been here five years and I still can't read all the street signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm a quicker learner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From OFF SCREEN:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicklaus-san.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick turns to see Ich, leaning against the door frame. He's already had a few drinks too many.  He's delighted t see Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've continued working on the case!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich ambles into the room, slips down into a chair.  He spills the contents of the large manila envelope he's bee carrying onto the table:  a wallet, a set of keys, playin cards, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (signaling to Joyce) Joyce... A drink please. (to Nick) Kobo has disappeared.  My superiors don't trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick walks over to the table and looks at the items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kobo's.  Taken off him when he was arrested in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick sits down.  Joyce gives Ich his scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd come back.  You feel you have a debt you can never pay. But you will, even if it costs you your life.  Giri.  Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick picks up various items off the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich drapes his arm over Nick's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Partners, Nicklaus-san?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich reaches for his drink.  Nick gets there first.  He holds it up as if he were proposing a toast, then purposefully spills his drink out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich has just had his last drink on duty.

dialogues.speaker: THE TABLE
dialogues.text: All the contents of the envelope are spread out on the table:  credit cards, matchbooks from New York City, choice clipping from Screw magazine, sugarless gum, cuff links... Nick's holding up a series of photos.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO
dialogues.text: of a naked women and Kobo screwing on a Tatami mat. Another photo.  Then another.  Each photo is more pornographic than the next. Joyce picks them up as Nick sets them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick holds out several of the same girl in various poses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) We can ask someone I used to work with.  A criminal.  Someone I pay money to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The largest in Tokyo.  Endless rows of men sitting in front of the machines (horizontal pinball games) furiousl punching the flippers.  The NOISE from the metal balls is deafening.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: in a Hawaiian shirt, his arms covered with tattoos, is starting a new game. Ich moves up to the vacant machine beside him, puts in hi change.  Ich doesn't face the man as they speak in Japanese.  The man in the Hawaiian shirt walks off.

dialogues.speaker: ON NICK
dialogues.text: as the man in the Hawaiian shirt walks past him.  This is the snitch.  Nick glances back at Ich.  Ich nods -- they're in business.

dialogues.speaker: A CRAMPED ROOM
dialogues.text: We HEAR the clattering of the machines outside.  The man in the Hawaiian shirt, mid-fifties and badly in need of a shower, is sitting on the floor studying the photos.  Ich and Nick tower above him. The man says something to Nick in Japanese, then continue to study the photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) He says they're very nice.  He wants to know if you have anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll ask him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ich asks in Japanese.  The man shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the man by his shirt collar and shoves him against the wall.  The photos spill to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is she?
